brief_summary.textblock:
Over the past year smartphones have developed from a niche product to a commoditized product
      and are now squeezing classic mobile phones out of market. According to a survey a quarter
      of the German population is making use of a smartphone at present.

      An interference between smartphones and the functionality of pacemakers or implantable
      defibrillators is rather unlikely but cannot entirely be excluded. A systematic study
      regarding a possible interference between smartphones and modern pacemaker- and ICD-system
      with a better shielding against external influence has not taken place so far. In this study
      the investigators intend to investigate any interference between different smartphones
      produced by different manufacturers and diverse cardiovascular implanted electronic devices.

clinical_study.brief_title: Safety of Smartphones Among Patients With Cardiac Implantable Electronic Devices
clinical_study.condition: Recipients of Implantable Pacemakers or Defibrillators

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Presence of an implantable pacemaker or defibrillator

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Lead malfunction which can not reprogrammed

          -  Battery depletion

study_pop.textblock: Recipients of implantable pacemakers or defibrillators

facility.name: Deutsches Herzzentrum München, Klinik für Herz- und Kreislauferkrankungen

clinical_study.official_title: Safety of Smartphones Among Patients With Cardiac Implantable Electronic Devices

primary_outcome.description: Interference testing will be performed during routine follow-up of pacemakers or defibrillators and potential interference will be recorded by ECG.
primary_outcome.measure: Interference of smartphones with cardiac implantable electronic devices

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Cross-Sectional
